Seeking Sylvester's 1878 paper on chemistry and invariant theory, I stumbled across this on Vicipædia. That's right: the *Latin* Wikipedia! Don't ask me why.

Then I found his actual paper here:

https://www.jstor.org/stable/2369436

Sylvester sure liked to write. For example:

"The more I study Dr. Frankland's wonderfully beautiful little treatise the more deeply I become impressed with the harmony or homology (I might call it, rather than analogy) which exists between the chemical and algebraical theories. In travelling my eye up and down the illustrated pages of "the Notes," I feel as Aladdin might have done in walking in the garden where every tree was laden with precious stones, or as Caspar Hauser when first brought out of his dark cellar to contemplate the glittering heavens on a starry night. There is an untold treasure of hoarded algebraical wealth potentially contained in the results achieved by the patient and long continued labor of our unconscious and unsuspected chemical fellow-workers."

But what did Sylvester actually do?

First he noticed that you can use graphs to describe molecules: vertices are atoms and edges are bonds. Nothing very new there. Then he noticed you can also use graphs to describe ways of building scalars from tensors: a vertex with n edges coming out is a tensor with n indices, and an edge means you sum over a repeated index, as in the 'Einstein summation convention'. This idea is often attributed to Penrose, who explained it more clearly much later.

Later still this became the math of 'string diagrams', popular in category theory.

Based on this, Sylvester tried to reduce chemistry to invariant theory. The idea has lots of problems, but it's a lot of fun!

It's always impressive when you see sci-fi films from the 50s and 60s that show TVs as widescreen -- often very close to today's 16:9 aspect ratio (e.g. "Fahrenheit 451" - 1966 - with its very large flat wide displays, and even small TVs in that aspect ratio. "2001: A Space Odyssey" -- 1968 -- is another obvious example).

Ironically, many later films and TV shows wanted to be more "authentic" and used actual CRT displays, meaning that they were virtually always in conventional 4:3 ratio and look hilariously dated for a story placed in the (sometimes far) future.

Sidenote: Shooting movie film in particular from a CRT was quite a trick in the earlier days, and various efforts were made to try avoid visual "hum bars" -- though they were never usually 100% successful. However, such shots (e.g. "The Manchurian Candidate" - 1962) do give a realistic sense of the time in these non-sci-fi films.

Since I brought up The Manchurian Candidate (and note I'm talking about the '62 version, not the completely forgettable recent remake), this is a very fine film, starring Frank Sinatra, Laurence Harvey, and Angela Lansbury (Lansbury in one of the most sinister and strange roles of her career, to be sure.)

The set piece of the film is a sequence near the beginning that involves transitioning between a Chinese brainwashing presentation and what appears to be the meeting of a women's garden club. This was shot in real time without any cuts, and is a marvel of stage and camera work. The screenplay was written by George Axelrod, who went on to write the screenplay for "Lord Love a Duck" (1966) -- an utterly different and bizarre kind of film that we will discuss in detail sometime in the future.

For now, "The Manchurian Candidate" is available for free (assume mostly U.S. only) on #YouTube Movies and TV. Highly recommended. But keep your card deck full of Queen of Diamonds nearby!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R3ZiN3nU4zY

title: In Japan, cherry blossom forecasting is a big deal. Warming is making it harder.

last_post.content:
🌸Did you know:

Japan has had a long-standing fixation with sakura (cherry blossoms) — in fact cherry blossom records date back to 812! This gives us a data set spanning 1211 years.

This has proven to be a treasure trove for scientists because they have been able to use this data to track a heating planet. (Pictured)

As a result cherry tree blossoms in Japan have been included in the “instrument dashboard” tracking our heating world.

(Graph source: https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2023/03/23/national/cherry-blossom-forecasting/)

title: Utopia achieved : a novel of the future : Brinsmade, Herman Hine : Free Download, Borrow, and Streaming : Internet Archive

last_post.content:
Utopia Achieved (1912) by Herman Hine Brinsmade (1876-1968), a slight utopian novel in the 19th century romance style by a minor journalist. Cute, but not worth a deep biography:

Brinsmade’s utopia is Steampunk USA: American cities are accessible either from above, via ports atop skyscrapers visited by airships; or from below, in layers of subways, each sunk beneath its predecessor. (The main character barely survives a horrific airship crash so uh I guess take the subway.)

An FDA-like health board has convinced Americans to adopt a vegetarian diet of dairy and carb mush consumed extremely slowly following the principles of Fletcherism. Here’s a sample menu from the far future of 1960:

Breakfast

Gluten gruel
Soft boiled egg
Creamed potato
Zweibach
Malt honey
Apple
Pecans

Dinner

Vegetable broth
Beans
Creamed potatoes
Cottage cheese
Graham puffs
Apple juice
Malt honey
Celery
Apples

Luncheon

Zweibach
Cherry sauce
Eggnog

Thanks to widespread consumption of well-masticated gruel, Brinsmade suggests the population of the US would rise to 200 million. (The actual figure in 1960 was 170 million, which hey, not a bad guess.)

A readable and inoffensive member of the utopian canon. The genuinely cool cover illustration is credited only to “Maurer.”

https://archive.org/details/utopiaachievedno00brin

title: Universal Declaration of Human Rights | United Nations

last_post.content:
Regarding #immigration, #asylum, and #refugees: there are several things that ought to be said.

1) Seeking asylum is human right.

https://www.un.org/en/about-us/universal-declaration-of-human-rights

3) We should bear in mind the objectives declared in our own immigration legislation, which boil down to (per its own language) saving the lives of refugees and offering protection to the displaced & persecuted.

Turning away *anyone* without even a suggestion of an effort to consider their claim is troubling, and allows our state to behave contrary to fundamental principles of justice. Not cool.

https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/i-2.5/page-1.html#h-274085

5) We have existing law that says our domestic Charter of Rights and Freedoms applies to everyone present in Canada, explicitly including foreign asylum seekers.

All of us enjoy important legal protections under the Charter, and I don't think that eroding the force and scope of the Charter is in the public interest.

https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/const/page-12.html

https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/singh-case
